content.description: Face climb follows the weakness.  Cleaning up nicely.
content.protection: Lots of trees for toprope anchors. An extended 25' anchor off a tree will allow a 100' toprope setup with a 70m rope.
content.location: The left side of the face, east end of the West End.

content.description: Great steep crack system.  Chossy - some expanding flakes on the faces will clean up.  First thirty feet offers steep face climbing to the crack system.
content.protection: No ground up ascent yet.  Trad lead probable. Maybe a bolt or two needed still.

content.description: Project.  Still some rock to remove.  The Oregon Grape crack is the prominent fist+ crack at the top of the formation.  There is an Oregon Grape bush growing out of the base of the crack.  The climb follows a beautiful orange crack at the base, angling right and up through a black water streak that is wet sometimes, then follows the arete to a platform where the Oregon Grape plant grows, follow the awkward fist+ crack for 20' to easy finish.  Variable rock quality but stellar positioning on a steep route.  I have no idea how hard it is but I started removing the loose rock and poison oak.
content.location: This is the most prominent line on the formation.

content.description: This varied crack system will clean up nicely with traffic.  From the ground climb up and left on reachy flakes to reach the crack system.  Climb behind the small tree up easy blocks and finish over a boulder to the top.  Anchor from trees on top, @40m
content.location: Begins climbers left of the prominent ToxicodendronTower, following left side of the yellow water streak before reaching the obvious crack system.  Finger, hand and forearm jams lead to a Doug Fir tree.  The crack gets wider, dirtier and easier behind the tree and finishes on top of the tower formation.  Toprope possible w extension from trees.

content.description: Mostly undeveloped,with loose rock on the top and some faces of the formation.  Several 100'+ walls have great potential and are being cleaned of loose rock, poison oak and moss before climbing and are decent moderate climbs.  Toprope from trees with extension.  Half a dozen unclimbed minor formations dot the hillside between this crag and the Brontosaurus area above the main road.  Visible from main road, around the corner as you leave Brontosaurus parking.
